title: US Late Session Slide
commentary: The selling intensified into the close — Dow tumbled 0.76%, S&P 500 lost 0.59%, Nasdaq dropped 0.63% — erasing Wednesday's gains in a broad-based retreat as risk appetite evaporated heading into Friday. Gold gave back most of its intraday gains but clung to the $5,010 handle, essentially flat on the day after touching the $5,034 record earlier. Oil remained stubbornly elevated at $66.49 (+2.2%), the one asset class traders seem reluctant to sell this week. Crypto drifted sideways in the wreckage — BTC $66,304 (-1.2%), ETH $1,918 (-2.7%) — with the broader digital asset complex clearly in a holding pattern awaiting a macro catalyst.

title: US Afternoon Selloff
commentary: Equities accelerated to the downside into the afternoon — S&P 500 fell 0.41%, Dow dropped 0.58% — as the early-session drift became a proper risk-off move with no single catalyst, just fading momentum after a week of mixed signals. Gold pulled back from its $5,034 intraday high but held above $5,020 (+0.23%), consolidating at nosebleed levels as bulls refuse to give ground. Crude oil remained the week's standout performer at $66.61 (+2.4%) while crypto treaded water — Bitcoin flat at $66,299 (-1.3% on 24h), ETH at $1,922 (-2.5%). The late-session weakness in equities heading into Friday could set up a cautious tone for the week's final trading day.

title: US Midday / Asia Midnight
commentary: Gold surged to a fresh all-time high of $5,034, adding nearly half a percent intraday as the precious metals complex refuses to quit — silver joined at $78.46 (+1.1%) in a relentless safe-haven bid. U.S. equities drifted lower through midday with the Dow off 0.3% and S&P down 0.17%, as Thursday's session lacked conviction following Wednesday's post-Fed minutes bounce. Crypto continued its week-long bleed with Bitcoin at $66,344 (-1.9%) and ETH sliding 3.1% to $1,923, marking a clear underperformance versus traditional risk assets. Oil stayed elevated above $66 on supply concerns while the dollar eased slightly to 97.84, offering no relief to the gold bears who remain completely run over.

title: US Morning Session
commentary: Stocks retreated from Wednesday's highs as Thursday's session opened lower — S&P 500 dipped 0.26%, Dow shed 0.4% — with profit-taking setting in after the post-Fed minutes rally faded. Gold pushed further into record territory at $5,017, shrugging off a firmer dollar (DXY 98.03, +0.3%) in a move that continues to confound traditional macro playbooks. Crude held above $66 (+2.1%) on persistent supply-side jitters while crypto stabilized modestly — Bitcoin recovered to $66,441 (-1.0% on 24h) after yesterday's sharp selloff. The tone is cautious with jobless claims data in focus and the hard-asset bid remaining the dominant theme of the week.

title: US Pre-Market / Asia Evening
commentary: Gold extended its run above $5,000, ticking up to $5,014 in overnight futures as the precious metals rally shows no signs of fatigue — silver followed suit at $78.29 (+0.9%) while crude held gains above $66 (+2.1%). U.S. equity futures are flat ahead of Thursday's open after Wednesday's solid session (S&P +0.56%, Nasdaq +0.78%) driven by receding AI fears and dovish-leaning Fed minutes. Crypto remains under pressure with Bitcoin sliding further to $65,887 (-1.9%) and ETH at $1,920 (-2.3%), extending the hard-asset rotation trade. The dollar index firmed to 97.92 as markets await fresh catalysts from Thursday's jobless claims data and existing home sales.

title: Post-Close Extended Session
commentary: The commodity complex stole the show in late U.S. trading — gold consolidated above $5,000 at $5,004 (+2.0%), silver ripped 4.9%, and crude surged 5% past $65 on escalating supply risks. Equities extended gains into the close with the Nasdaq leading at +0.78% as AI worries receded and Fed minutes confirmed a patient rate stance. Crypto continues to bleed in the opposite direction — Bitcoin down 2.2% to $66,253 and ETH off 2.7% — underperforming as institutional flows rotate into precious metals. The dollar index held firm at 97.73 (+0.6%), making gold's breakout above the psychological $5,000 level all the more impressive against a strengthening greenback.

title: Overnight US Close Recap
commentary: Wall Street closed modestly higher with Nvidia leading a tech rally — S&P 500 +0.35%, Nasdaq +0.52% — as traders digested Fed minutes showing policymakers in no rush to cut rates further. The real fireworks were in commodities: gold punched through $5,000 to close at $5,001 (+1.9%), silver surged 4.4%, and crude oil jumped 4.3% on escalating geopolitical tensions and supply concerns. Crypto went the opposite direction — Bitcoin slid 2.5% to $66,077 and ETH dropped 3.3% to $1,932 in a clear risk-rotation into hard assets. The dollar index firmed 0.6% to 97.72, adding to gold's remarkable run that now defies traditional correlations.

title: Asia Pre-Dawn Selloff
commentary: Crypto took a sharp leg lower in the 2-3 AM SGT window — Bitcoin dropped 2.4% to $66,316 and Ethereum shed 2.3% to $1,953 as the brief constructive tone evaporated in thin overnight liquidity. The move came despite equities holding gains (Nikkei +1.0%, Hang Seng +0.5%) and the dollar strengthening on U.S.-Iran progress, suggesting crypto-specific deleveraging rather than a broad risk-off event. Gold remains under pressure below $5,000 with the stronger greenback capping any recovery attempts. Oil continues to find support on the dual geopolitical bid from Iran tensions and the Russia-Ukraine stalemate, keeping crude elevated even as macro headwinds persist.

title: Early Morning Asia
commentary: Global equities pushed higher as U.S.-Iran diplomatic progress lifted risk appetite — the Dow gained ground with tech stocks leading, while the dollar firmed on the détente narrative. Bitcoin flatlined at $67,132 (essentially unchanged on 24h) and ETH held $1,973 (+0.4%) as crypto traded in a tight overnight range with no fresh catalysts. Gold remains pinned below $5,000 as the stronger dollar and easing geopolitical fears sap safe-haven demand, though analysts maintain the pullback is corrective. The session's tone is cautiously constructive heading into Wednesday's full trading day, with the "sell America" contrarian call providing the only counterweight to the broad risk-on tilt.

title: Post-Midnight Asia
commentary: Bitcoin surrendered its late-session bounce, sliding back to $67,111 (-0.6%) as ETH drifted to $1,971 (-0.4%) in thin overnight liquidity. Crude oil found fresh support on a dual catalyst — a Russia-Ukraine peace deadlock and escalating U.S.-Iran rhetoric — keeping WTI elevated despite broader oversupply headwinds. Gold continues to consolidate just below $5,000 with dip-buyers lurking; the corrective pullback thesis remains intact as geopolitical hedging demand shows no signs of abating. Markets enter the Wednesday session with a cautious undertone as the "sell America" narrative lingers and traders await fresh catalysts.
